choices.text: The membranous septum lies posterior to the perpendicular plate of ethmoid
The columellar septum is made up of septal cartilage and covered by nasal mucosa
The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the bony part of the septum proper
The membranous septum is supported by the vomer and palatine crest

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes a component of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the bony part of the septum proper

 

  • It forms the superior portion of the osteocartilaginous septum proper.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The membranous septum lies posterior to the perpendicular plate of ethmoid: Incorrect. The membranous septum lies anterior to the septal cartilage, not posterior to the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid.

 

Option B. The columellar septum is made up of septal cartilage and covered by nasal mucosa: Incorrect. The columellar septum consists of the medial crura of the alar cartilages, united by fibrous tissue and covered by skin, not mucosa.

 

Option D. The membranous septum is supported by the vomer and palatine crest: Incorrect. The membranous septum has no bony or cartilaginous support, consisting only of skin layers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The perpendicular plate of ethmoid is a major bony component of the septum proper, forming the superior part of the nasal septum.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 147

choices.text: Located on the posterior nasal cavity; supplied by the posterior ethmoidal and sphenopalatine arteries
Located on the anterosuperior nasal septum; supplied primarily by the internal maxillary artery
Located just above the nasal vestibule; formed by an arterial plexus involving anterior ethmoidal, superior labial, and sphenopalatine arteries
Located on the inferior turbinate; supplied predominantly by the descending palatine and facial arteries

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous anterior nasal bleeding, especially during winter. On anterior rhinoscopy, you observe a small vascular lesion in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Which of the following best explains the location and vascular supply of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Located just above the nasal vestibule; formed by an arterial plexus involving anterior ethmoidal, superior labial, and sphenopalatine arteries

 

Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s plexus) is located anteroinferiorly, just above the nasal vestibule and formed by the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Located on the posterior nasal cavity; supplied by the posterior ethmoidal and sphenopalatine arteries: Incorrect. This describes Woodruff’s plexus, which is involved in posterior epistaxis, not Little’s area.

 

Option B. Located on the anterosuperior nasal septum; supplied primarily by the internal maxillary artery: Incorrect. The anteroinferior septum, not the anterosuperior part, is where Kiesselbach’s plexus is located.

 

Option D. Located on the inferior turbinate; supplied predominantly by the descending palatine and facial arteries: Incorrect. This does not refer to Little’s area; inferior turbinate bleeding is less common and not the site for Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s plexus) is the most common site of anterior epistaxis, located anteroinferiorly on the nasal septum and formed by an arterial anastomosis involving the anterior ethmoidal, superior labial, sphenopalatine, and greater palatine arteries.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 147

choices.text: Chevallet fracture – vertical fracture from anterior nasal spine to cartilaginous dorsum
Jarjaway fracture – horizontal fracture from anterior nasal spine to septal cartilage-vomer junction
Greenstick fracture – incomplete fracture of the nasal bone commonly seen in children
Septal hematoma – collection of blood between septal cartilage and mucoperichondrium

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining facial trauma during a fistfight. Examination reveals tenderness and deviation of the nasal septum. Imaging reveals a horizontal fracture starting above the anterior nasal spine and running backward just above the junction of the septal cartilage and vomer. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jarjaway fracture – horizontal fracture from anterior nasal spine to septal cartilage-vomer junction

 

This is caused by blows from the front and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of the septal cartilage and vomer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chevallet fracture – vertical fracture from anterior nasal spine to cartilaginous dorsum: Incorrect. This is caused by blows from below and results in a vertical fracture running upwards from the anterior nasal spine to the junction of bony and cartilaginous dorsum.

 

 

Option C. Greenstick fracture – incomplete fracture of the nasal bone commonly seen in children: Incorrect. This refers to partial or incomplete fractures, typically seen in pediatric nasal bone injuries, and does not describe the course given.

 

Option D. Septal hematoma – collection of blood between septal cartilage and mucoperichondrium: Incorrect. This is not a fracture but a collection of blood following trauma, often presenting with bilateral nasal obstruction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Jarjaway fracture is a horizontal nasal septal fracture resulting from frontal trauma, running just above the anterior nasal spine and along the septal cartilage-vomer junction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 147

choices.text: Prescribe oral antibiotics and reassess in a week
Drain the hematoma, reposition septal fragments, suture mucoperichondrial flaps, and apply nasal packing
Perform reduction of nasal bones only and observe septal injury conservatively
Wait for edema to subside and plan cosmetic rhinoplasty after 6 weeks

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic 3 days after a road traffic accident with swelling and tenderness over the nose. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals a deviated nasal septum and suspected septal hematoma. What is the most appropriate immediate management of this condition to prevent long-term complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drain the hematoma, reposition septal fragments, suture mucoperichondrial flaps, and apply nasal packing

 

This is the recommended treatment for septal injury with or without hematoma to prevent cartilage necrosis, deviation, and deformities.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe oral antibiotics and reassess in a week: Incorrect. Delay in treating septal hematoma can lead to abscess formation, cartilage necrosis, and deformities.

 

Option C. Perform reduction of nasal bones only and observe septal injury conservatively: Incorrect. Septal injuries often coexist with nasal fractures and must be treated together to avoid long-term cosmetic and functional issues.

 

Option D. Wait for edema to subside and plan cosmetic rhinoplasty after 6 weeks: Incorrect. Waiting delays critical treatment. Functional management must be done early; rhinoplasty is for residual deformities later.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early drainage of septal hematoma and repositioning of septal fractures with internal splinting is essential to prevent nasal deformities and asymmetry.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 148

choices.text: Birth trauma during difficult labor
Unequal growth between the palate and the skull base
High-arched palate in adenoid hypertrophy
Chronic allergic rhinitis causing mucosal hypertrophy

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with chronic nasal obstruction and mouth breathing. Examination reveals a deviated nasal septum. Which of the following is not a recognized cause of DNS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic allergic rhinitis causing mucosal hypertrophy

 

While allergic rhinitis causes nasal obstruction, it affects the turbinate mucosa, not the septum structurally. It does not cause DNS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth trauma during difficult labor: Correct cause. Trauma at birth can cause septal cartilage displacement leading to deviation later in life.

 

Option B. Unequal growth between the palate and the skull base: Correct cause. Developmental error due to mismatch in growth of palate and skull base can lead to DNS.

 

Option C. High-arched palate in adenoid hypertrophy: Correct cause. Mouth breathing due to adenoids results in high-arched palate and deviated septum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deviated nasal septum can result from trauma, developmental errors, hereditary and racial factors, but not from mucosal conditions like allergic rhinitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 148

choices.text: 2, 3 and 4 are true
1, 2, and 3 are true
All except 1 are true
Only 3 and 4 are true

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding types of septal deformities are true?

 

  1. Anterior dislocation of septal cartilage is best appreciated by examining the patient with the head tilted forward.
  2. C-shaped deformity may cause compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on the wider nasal side.
  3. An S-shaped deformity in the anteroposterior plane may cause bilateral nasal obstruction.
  4. Spurs in the nasal septum are common at the bone-cartilage junction and may cause repeated epistaxis.
  5. Septal thickening can result from an organized haematoma or overriding fractured fragments.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) All except 1 are true

 

Statement 2. C-shaped deformity may cause compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on the wider nasal side: True. In C-shaped deviation, the concave side has a wider nasal cavity and may develop compensatory turbinate hypertrophy.

 

 

Statement 3. An S-shaped deformity in the anteroposterior plane may cause bilateral nasal obstruction: True. S-shaped deformities (vertical or anteroposterior) may block both nasal passages, causing bilateral obstruction.

 

 

Statement 4. Spurs in the nasal septum are common at the bone-cartilage junction and may cause repeated epistaxis: True. Septal spurs, especially at bone-cartilage junction, may press against the lateral wall and stretch mucosal vessels, leading to headaches or epistaxis.

 

 

Statement 5. Septal thickening can result from an organized haematoma or overriding fractured fragments: True. Septal thickening can be due to organized haematoma or overriding of fractured/dislocated fragments.

 

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 1. Anterior dislocation of septal cartilage is best appreciated by examining the patient with the head tilted forward: False. Incorrect orientation mentioned. Anterior dislocation is best seen by tilting the head backward, not forward.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deformities of the nasal septum include anterior dislocation, C- and S-shaped curves, spurs, and thickening, most of which can lead to nasal obstruction or complications like turbinate hypertrophy or epistaxis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 149

choices.text: Bilateral nasal obstruction in high septal deviation
Epistaxis due to crusting over the deviated septum
Recurrent middle ear infections due to Eustachian tube dysfunction
Hyposmia due to obstruction at the level of the choanae

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction, headache, occasional nosebleeds, and decreased sense of smell. On anterior rhinoscopy, a septal spur is noted pressing against the lateral nasal wall. Which of the following features is not typically associated with Deviated Nasal Septum (DNS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyposmia due to obstruction at the level of the choanae

 

Hyposmia occurs due to failure of air to reach the olfactory region (upper nasal cavity), not due to choanal obstruction. Choanal obstruction is more typical of conditions like choanal atresia or polyps, not DNS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral nasal obstruction in high septal deviation: True. High DNS may block airflow through the upper nasal passage, resulting in bilateral nasal obstruction due to airflow dynamics.

 

Option B. Epistaxis due to crusting over the deviated septum: True. Air currents dry out the mucosa over the deviated septum, causing crusting which can lead to epistaxis.

 

Option C. Recurrent middle ear infections due to Eustachian tube dysfunction: True. DNS can impair nasal ventilation and predispose to middle ear infections by interfering with Eustachian tube function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deviated Nasal Septum can lead to nasal obstruction, sinusitis, epistaxis, hyposmia, headaches, middle ear infections, and external nasal deformities, but choanal obstruction is not a typical cause of olfactory loss in DNS.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 149

choices.text: Deviated nasal septum causing choanal obstruction
Hypertrophy of the inferior turbinates
Abnormality of the nasal valve area
Nasopharyngeal mass causing posterior obstruction

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with complaints of nasal obstruction, especially during inspiration. On physical examination, his symptoms improve when his cheek is pulled laterally while he breathes quietly through his nose. What does a positive Cottle test indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abnormality of the nasal valve area

 

The Cottle test is specifically designed to assess the patency of the nasal valve, which is the narrowest part of the nasal airway. If pulling the cheek laterally improves airflow, it indicates collapse or narrowing of the vestibular/nasal valve area.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deviated nasal septum causing choanal obstruction: While DNS can cause nasal obstruction, it does not improve with lateral traction of the cheek. So the Cottle test is not used to assess DNS.

 

Option B. Hypertrophy of the inferior turbinates: This causes obstruction but is not relieved by the Cottle maneuver. It is usually diagnosed via endoscopy or anterior rhinoscopy.

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal mass causing posterior obstruction: This causes posterior nasal obstruction, often associated with symptoms like nasal regurgitation or Eustachian tube dysfunction. It would not be affected by the Cottle test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Cottle test indicates vestibular (nasal valve) abnormality as the cause of nasal obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 149

choices.text: Submucous resection (SMR) involves bilateral flap elevation and complete removal of septal cartilage
Septoplasty is avoided in adults due to the risk of disturbing nasal growth
SMR is preferred over septoplasty due to better airway results
Septoplasty is a conservative procedure where only the most deviated portion of the septum is corrected

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with chronic nasal obstruction and recurrent sinusitis. On anterior rhinoscopy, he is found to have a deviated nasal septum. He is advised surgery. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the surgical options for deviated nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Septoplasty is a conservative procedure where only the most deviated portion of the septum is corrected

 

Septoplasty preserves the majority of septal framework, corrects only the problematic parts, and usually involves unilateral flap elevation, reducing trauma and preserving blood supply.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submucous resection (SMR) involves bilateral flap elevation and complete removal of septal cartilage: Incorrect. While SMR involves elevation of both mucoperichondrial and mucoperiosteal flaps, it does not involve complete removal of the entire septal cartilage—only the deflected portions are removed. Also, it is a more radical procedure than needed in many cases today.

 

Option B. Septoplasty is avoided in adults due to the risk of disturbing nasal growth: Incorrect. Septoplasty is actually preferred in adults. Surgery is usually deferred until after 17 years of age to avoid disturbing nasal growth in children, not in adults.

 

Option C. SMR is preferred over septoplasty due to better airway results: Incorrect. SMR has now largely been replaced by septoplasty, which is more conservative and preserves structural support. Septoplasty provides adequate airway improvement with fewer complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septoplasty is a conservative surgical procedure for deviated nasal septum where only the deviated parts are corrected, preserving most of the septal framework.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 149

choices.text: Prescribe oral decongestants and monitor
Incision and drainage with bilateral nasal packing
Immediate septoplasty
Reassure and follow-up after a week

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and headache after a fall during a football match. On anterior rhinoscopy, a smooth, soft, fluctuant swelling is seen on both sides of the septum. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage with bilateral nasal packing

 

This is the treatment of choice for large septal haematomas. Drainage prevents complications like septal abscess, cartilage necrosis, and saddle nose deformity. Packing prevents reaccumulation of blood, and antibiotics are given to prevent infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe oral decongestants and monitor: Incorrect. This approach delays definitive treatment. Septal haematomas can lead to cartilage necrosis and deformity if not drained promptly.

 

Option C. Immediate septoplasty: Incorrect. Septoplasty is indicated for deviated nasal septum, not for haematoma. Surgical drainage is sufficient unless structural deformity develops later.

 

Option D. Reassure and follow-up after a week: Incorrect. Delay in treatment may lead to secondary infection and irreversible cartilage damage. Timely intervention is critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal haematoma must be promptly incised and drained with nasal packing to prevent complications like septal abscess and saddle nose deformity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 149

choices.text: CT scan of paranasal sinuses to assess sinusitis
High-dose steroids to reduce mucosal inflammation
Incision and drainage with systemic antibiotics
Septoplasty followed by nasal packing

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with fever, bilateral nasal obstruction, swelling over the bridge of the nose, and tenderness for 3 days. On anterior rhinoscopy, bilateral smooth septal swelling is noted with fluctuation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage with systemic antibiotics

 

This is the definitive treatment. The abscess must be incised and drained urgently. Any necrotic cartilage should be removed, and systemic antibiotics are started immediately to prevent complications like meningitis, septal perforation, and saddle nose deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan of paranasal sinuses to assess sinusitis: Incorrect. While imaging may help in some nasal pathologies, this is a clear case of septal abscess, where immediate intervention is required. Delay can risk cartilage necrosis and intracranial complications.

 

Option B. High-dose steroids to reduce mucosal inflammation: Incorrect. Steroids are contraindicated in acute infections like abscesses as they suppress immunity and worsen the infection.

 

Option D. Septoplasty followed by nasal packing: Incorrect. Septoplasty is a planned procedure for deviated nasal septum and is not appropriate in the acute setting of infection. Immediate drainage, not structural correction, is the priority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal abscess requires urgent incision, drainage, and systemic antibiotics to prevent cartilage necrosis, septal perforation, or saddle nose deformity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 150

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis
Prolonged intranasal steroid spray use
Chronic granulomatous disease
Intranasal cocaine abuse

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with complaints of nasal congestion, recurrent epistaxis, and a whistling sound while breathing. He admits to long-term recreational drug use. On examination, there is a small anterior septal perforation. What is the most likely cause of his nasal findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intranasal cocaine abuse

 

Cocaine is a potent vasoconstrictor. Chronic intranasal use causes ischemia and necrosis of the septal cartilage, leading to perforation. The whistling sound during breathing and history of drug use are classic clues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis: Incorrect. This can cause nasal congestion and discharge but does not typically cause septal perforation.

 

Option B. Prolonged intranasal steroid spray use: Incorrect. While steroid sprays can cause mucosal thinning, perforation is rare unless abused excessively or combined with other factors.

 

Option C. Chronic granulomatous disease: Incorrect. Granulomatous conditions (e.g., tuberculosis, syphilis, Wegener’s) can cause perforation but are less likely in a young adult with drug use history and no systemic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic intranasal cocaine use causes septal perforation due to ischemic necrosis from vasoconstriction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 151

choices.text: External auditory canal stenosis
Retraction of columella
Synechiae of the vocal cords
Inferior turbinate hypertrophy

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with persistent nasal obstruction and frequent headaches is planned for submucous resection (SMR) of the nasal septum. Which of the following is a known complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retraction of columella

 

This occurs when the caudal strip of cartilage is not preserved during SMR, leading to columellar collapse—a known complication.

 

Complications of SMR & Septoplasty Surgeries

 

  1. Bleeding
    • May require nasal repacking if severe.
  2. Septal Hematoma
    • Blood collects under mucoperichondrium.
    • Needs evacuation and nasal packing on both sides.
  3. Septal Abscess
    • May occur if hematoma becomes infected.
  4. Septal Perforation
    • Happens when mucosa is torn on both sides.
  5. Depression of Nasal Bridge (Supratip area)
    • Caused by excessive removal of cartilage along dorsal border.
  6. Retraction of Columella
    • Occurs when caudal cartilage is not preserved.
  7. Persistence of Deviation
    • Due to inadequate surgery. May need revision.
  8. Flapping Septum
    • Seen when too much of septal framework is removed.
    • Septum flutters with breathing.

  9. Toxic Shock Syndrome (rare)

    • Caused by staph or strep infection.
    • Symptoms: Fever, vomiting, hypotension, rash, purulent discharge.
    • Management: Remove nasal packing, IV fluids, antibiotics, support BP.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. External auditory canal stenosis: Incorrect. This is unrelated to septal surgery; it is seen in chronic otitis externa or trauma.

 

Option C. Synechiae of the vocal cords: Incorrect. Synechiae between vocal cords are related to laryngeal trauma or surgery, not nasal septal procedures.

 

Option D. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: Incorrect. This is often a cause of nasal obstruction and may co-exist with DNS, but it is not a complication of SMR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retraction of the columella is a complication of SMR that occurs when the caudal strip of septal cartilage is not preserved.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 414

choices.text: Incise the opposite mucoperichondrium directly through the septum
Remove the cartilage and bone before lifting opposite flap
Incise the septal cartilage just posterior to initial mucoperichondrial incision
Make a curvilinear incision through the cartilage at the mucocutaneous junction of the right side

questions.text: A 25-year-old male undergoes Submucous Resection (SMR) for symptomatic deviated nasal septum. During surgery, the mucoperichondrial flap is raised on one side. What is the most appropriate next step in the surgical sequence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incise the septal cartilage just posterior to initial mucoperichondrial incision

 

After elevating the mucoperichondrial flap on one side, the cartilage is incised just posterior to the first incision. This incision allows access to the opposite side to elevate the second flap.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incise the opposite mucoperichondrium directly through the septum: Incorrect. You must not directly incise the opposite mucoperichondrium. It should be elevated carefully after cartilage incision to avoid septal perforation.

 

Option B. Remove the cartilage and bone before lifting opposite flap: Incorrect. Cartilage and bone are removed after elevating both flaps to prevent damage and ensure clear visualization.

 

Option D. Make a curvilinear incision through the cartilage at the mucocutaneous junction of the right side: Incorrect. The incision is made on left side (standard approach) at the mucocutaneous junction — but not through cartilage immediately and not on the right side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SMR surgery, the septal cartilage is incised just posterior to the mucoperichondrial incision after elevating the flap on one side to allow access for opposite flap elevation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 414

choices.text: To localize the source of epistaxis
To obtain a targeted biopsy from the nasopharynx
To monitor treatment response in sinus disease
To treat a maxillary sinus mucocele

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with chronic nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of nasal bleeding. Physical examination is inconclusive. Which of the following is not a valid indication for performing Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy (DNE)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To treat a maxillary sinus mucocele

 

Treatment of sinus pathologies like a maxillary mucocele generally requires surgical intervention, not merely diagnostic nasal endoscopy. DNE helps in diagnosis, not definitive treatment of such lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To localize the source of epistaxis: Correct indication. DNE is used to identify the precise source of bleeding in patients with epistaxis.

 

Option B. To obtain a targeted biopsy from the nasopharynx: Correct indication. DNE allows precise and minimally invasive biopsy from the nose or nasopharynx.

 

Option C. To monitor treatment response in sinus disease: Correct indication. It is valuable for assessing treatment response in diseases of the nose and paranasal sinuses (PNS), whether medical or surgical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy is used for diagnosis, biopsy, and assessing treatment response, but not for definitive treatment of conditions like mucoceles.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 417

choices.text: Nasolacrimal duct opening
Eustachian tube orifice
Middle turbinate and hiatus semilunaris
Sphenoethmoidal recess and sphenoid sinus opening

questions.text: Which of the following structures is best visualized during the second pass of diagnostic nasal endoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess and sphenoid sinus opening

 

  • These are specifically examined during the second pass, where the endoscope is passed medial to the middle turbinate to visualize:
    • Sphenoethmoidal recess
    • Superior turbinate and meatus
    • Posterior ethmoidal cells
    • Sphenoid sinus opening

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasolacrimal duct opening: Seen during first pass, specifically in the inferior meatus, often confirmed by gentle pressure over the lacrimal sac.

 

Option B. Eustachian tube orifice: Also seen during the first pass while entering the nasopharynx via the floor of the nose.

 

Option C. Middle turbinate and hiatus semilunaris: These are examined during the third pass while evaluating the middle meatus using a 30° endoscope.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sphenoethmoidal recess and sphenoid sinus opening are examined during the second pass of diagnostic nasal endoscopy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 417

choices.text: Immediate open septorhinoplasty
Wait for 7–10 days and then attempt closed reduction
Immediate reduction with Walsham forceps
Reassure and observe, as no intervention is needed

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with nasal swelling, bruising over the nasal bridge, and difficulty breathing through his nose after a motorbike accident. There is tenderness and crepitus over the nasal bones, and the nasal bridge appears flattened. No active epistaxis or septal hematoma is noted. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wait for 7–10 days and then attempt closed reduction

 

In cases with nasal edema, it is best to wait until swelling subsides (7–10 days) for accurate reduction. Walsham forceps are used for nasal bone reduction. Asch forces are used for septal reduction or elevation

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate open septorhinoplasty: Incorrect. Open rhinoplasty is reserved for long-standing deformities or failed conservative treatments, typically after 3 months.

 

Option C. Immediate reduction with Walsham forceps: Incorrect. While Walsham forceps are used, edema impairs judgment of fracture alignment, so it's better to delay for a few days unless swelling is minimal.

 

Option D. Reassure and observe, as no intervention is needed: Incorrect. The patient has signs of nasal bone fracture with deformity, which needs reduction to avoid long-term cosmetic and functional issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nasal bone trauma with edema, closed reduction using Walsham forceps is best done after 7–10 days when swelling subsides.

 

Ref: Isaacson G. Walsham, Asch, and Goldman. Ear, Nose & Throat Journal. 2023;103(4):205-207.

choices.text: Sphenopalatine artery
Septal branch of superior labial artery
Inferior alveolar artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent anterior epistaxis. On nasal examination, bleeding is localized to the Little’s area on the anterior part of the nasal septum. Which of the following arteries is not a contributor to the vascular supply of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior alveolar artery


It is a branch of the maxillary artery, but supplies the mandible and lower teeth, not the nasal septum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sphenopalatine artery: Contributes. It is a terminal branch of the maxillary artery (external carotid system) and gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches to the septum.

 

Option B. Septal branch of superior labial artery: Contributes. This is a branch of the facial artery, another external carotid branch, and supplies the anterior septum.

 

Option D. Anterior ethmoidal artery: Contributes. A branch of the ophthalmic artery (internal carotid system), it supplies the anterior nasal septum and contributes to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nasal septum receives arterial supply from both internal (anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries) and external carotid systems (sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial arteries); inferior alveolar artery is not involved.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 176

choices.text: Common in children, originates from Kiesselbach’s plexus, usually mild
Due to trauma, originates from the anterior septum, easily controlled
Spontaneous, difficult to localize, requires posterior nasal packing
Mild bleeding from the anterior part of the lateral nasal wall, self-limiting

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive male presents with profuse nasal bleeding. The bleeding does not stop with anterior nasal packing and continues to drip into the oropharynx. He denies any history of trauma. Which of the following best characterizes this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spontaneous, difficult to localize, requires posterior nasal packing

 

Posterior epistaxis is spontaneous, more common in elderly, and often associated with hypertension or arteriosclerosis. It’s usually difficult to localize, severe, and may require posterior nasal packing or even hospitalization.

 

Differences Between Anterior and Posterior Epistaxis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common in children, originates from Kiesselbach’s plexus, usually mild: Incorrect. Describes anterior epistaxis, which is common in children and mild.

 

Option B. Due to trauma, originates from the anterior septum, easily controlled: Incorrect. Also refers to anterior bleeding, typically trauma-related.

 

Option D. Mild bleeding from the anterior part of the lateral nasal wall, self-limiting: Incorrect – Again describes a mild anterior epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior epistaxis occurs in older adults, is usually spontaneous, difficult to localize, and often requires posterior nasal packing due to severe bleeding.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 178

choices.text: Ligation of external carotid artery above the level of superior thyroid artery
Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL)
Anterior ethmoidal artery ligation at the anterior lacrimal crest
Direct cauterization of anterior nasal septum using silver nitrate

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with active nasal bleeding not controlled by anterior and posterior nasal packing. He has no bleeding diathesis and is hemodynamically stable. Endoscopic evaluation localizes the bleeding to the posterior nasal cavity. What is the next most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL)

 

This is the preferred surgical step after failure of conservative measures (like packing), as it targets the main posterior nasal blood supply directly at the sphenopalatine foramen (1 cm behind middle turbinate).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of external carotid artery above the level of superior thyroid artery: Incorrect. This is considered only after failure of sphenopalatine and maxillary artery ligation. It's a more invasive step and compromises multiple vascular branches.

 

Option C. Anterior ethmoidal artery ligation at the anterior lacrimal crest: Incorrect. Ethmoidal artery ligation is for internal carotid system bleeds, done later in the escalation ladder when previous steps fail.

 

Option D. Direct cauterization of anterior nasal septum using silver nitrate: Incorrect. This is an early measure only used in anterior epistaxis, especially when the bleeding site is visible (e.g., Little’s area).

 

Educational Objective:

 

TESPAL is the preferred surgical step for controlling posterior epistaxis when nasal packing fails, as it ligates the sphenopalatine artery directly under endoscopic guidance.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 179

choices.text: Wegener's Granulomatosis
Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome
Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
Hemophilia A

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent spontaneous epistaxis since adolescence. On examination, telangiectatic spots are noted on her lips and oral mucosa. There is no history of trauma or bleeding diathesis. Imaging reveals arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) in the lungs and liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome

 

  • Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by:
    • Recurrent epistaxis
    • Mucocutaneous telangiectasias
    • AVMs in lungs, liver, GI tract, CNS
    • Caused by abnormal vessel wall structure (deficient muscle/elastic tissue)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener’s Granulomatosis: Incorrect. This is a granulomatous vasculitis involving the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys. It may cause epistaxis but not mucocutaneous telangiectasias or systemic AVMs.

 

Option C. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: Incorrect. This is a vascular tumor seen in adolescent males, not females, and doesn’t cause systemic AVMs or mucosal telangiectasia.

 

Option D. Hemophilia A: Incorrect. X-linked bleeding disorder with factor VIII deficiency; presents with deep bleeding (e.g., hemarthrosis), not telangiectasias or AVMs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osler-Weber-Rendu disease is an autosomal dominant condition presenting with recurrent epistaxis, mucocutaneous telangiectasias, and systemic AVMs.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 180
